title: 107_hr2420
content: The Act may be cited as the "Peopling of America Theme Study Act" and includes findings and purposes. Congress finds that the migration, immigration, and settlement of the population of the United States, broadly termed the "peopling of America," is characterized by the movement of groups of people across boundaries and their interactions, with each group making unique contributions to American history, culture, art, and life. The diversity of the American population has contributed to the vitality of the United States in various aspects such as culture, politics, and economics. Embracing diversity has strengthened the nation and unified it in values, institutions, and accomplishments. The National Park Service ensures the representation of the full diversity of American history and prehistory. The National Park Service aims to represent the diversity of American history and prehistory by focusing on human population movement and settlement. Despite the large number of historic listings, sites related to various cultures exploring and settling in the United States are underrepresented. The purpose of this Act is to promote understanding and appreciation of the contributions of diverse groups who have populated the country. The purpose of this Act is to promote understanding and appreciation of the contributions of diverse groups who have populated the United States, and to strengthen the National Park Service's ability to include groups and events not typically recognized in American history. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "theme study" is the national historic landmark theme study required under section 4. The term "peopling of America" refers to the migration, immigration, and settlement of the population of the United States. The Secretary is required to prepare a national historic landmark theme study on the peopling of America to identify key events and sites that shaped the culture and society of the United States. The study will recommend new national historic landmarks for designation. The theme study will include a list of appropriate sites for national historic landmark designation and encourage nominations to the National Register of Historic Places. The Secretary will designate new national historic landmarks based on the study. Additionally, the theme study will identify sites within the National Park System for interpreting the peopling of America and recommend new sites for potential inclusion in the National Park. The Secretary will evaluate, identify, and designate new national historic landmarks, as well as recommend sites for potential inclusion in the National Park System based on the theme study. Additionally, the Secretary may establish linkages between regions, areas, trails, districts, communities, and sites for public education and research. The Secretary may establish linkages between regions, areas, trails, districts, communities, sites, buildings, structures, objects, organizations, societies, and cultures for public education and research purposes. The Secretary aims to create linkages to enhance public education and research on the peopling of America. Cooperative arrangements will be made with various entities to preserve and interpret key sites. The documentation will be used for educational initiatives such as popular publications and curriculum materials. The Secretary will implement cooperative programs to encourage the preservation and interpretation of the peopling of America through curriculum materials, heritage tourism products, and oral history programs. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with educational institutions, professional associations, or other entities knowledgeable about the peopling of America to prepare a theme study, ensure it meets scholarly standards, and promote cooperative programs related to the peopling of America.
